intro: Archibaccharis subsessilis, commonly known as the narrow-leaved hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its narrow, lance-shaped leaves and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. It typically grows in wetlands and along the edges of ponds, preferring moist to swampy soils. The species is noted for its ornamental value and its ability to thrive in humid, tropical-like conditions.
